Title.evidence: DESIGN: Systematic review of randomised controlled trials with meta-analysis.

Trial_Design.evidence: DESIGN: Systematic review of randomised controlled trials with meta-analysis.

Participants.evidence: ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA: Randomised controlled trials, which compared the intravenous with perineural administration of dexamethasone as a local anaesthetic adjunct in peripheral nerve blocks for surgery of the lower limb.

Intervention.evidence: ELIGIBILITY CRITERIA: Randomised controlled trials, which compared the intravenous with perineural administration of dexamethasone as a local anaesthetic adjunct in peripheral nerve blocks for surgery of the lower limb.

Objective.evidence: OBJECTIVES: To compare the pharmacodynamic characteristics of intravenous and perineural dexamethasone in the lower limb.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome, the duration of analgesia, was investigated by all nine trials ( n = 546 patients).

Number_Randomised.evidence: The primary outcome, the duration of analgesia, was investigated by all nine trials ( n = 546 patients).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Overall, compared with intravenous dexamethasone, perineural dexamethasone increased the duration of analgesia from 19.54 to 22.27 h, a mean difference [95% confidence interval (CI) of 2.73 (1.07 to 4.38) h; P = 0.001, I 2 = 87].

Harms.evidence: No differences were shown for any of the secondary outcomes related to efficacy and side effects.
